results.title: Hansel and Gretel by Engelbert Humperdinck
results.creator_credit: Elijah Moshinsky, Virginia Lumsden, ABC-TV (Australia) and Opera Australia
results.brief_description: Based on the Brothers Grimm fairytale, Englebert Humperdinck’s opera adaptation of “Hansel and Gretel” is for both adults and children alike. This fantastic Opera Australia production of the story provides a strong visual interpretation of the opera, with wonderfully surreal sets designed by Mark Thompson. Performers include: Suzanne Johnston, Christine Douglas, Elizabeth Campbell, Malcolm Donnelly, Gail Robertson. The Australian Opera (Australia) conducted by Johannes Fritzch. Staged by Elijah Moshinsky. Sung in English Translation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Elijah Moshinsky, Virginia Lumsden, ABC-TV (Australia) and Opera Australia

results.title: Hansel and Gretel
results.creator_credit: John Paul, Michael Myerberg and Hansel and Gretel Co
results.brief_description: Children will love this adaptation of the famous Grimm fairy tale featuring life like marionettes (called Kinemins), authentic scenery and a musical soundtrack by Engelbert Humperdinck. Two children explore the forest in search of strawberries but are caught by the wicked witch who has a nasty habit of turning children into gingerbread. The original play was written by Adelaide Witty and adapted for the screen by Padraic Colum. Warning; The image drops out after the copyright warning but reappears before the video begins.

results.title: Hans Richter: early works
results.creator_credit: Hans Richter, Re:Voir and Cecile Starr
results.brief_description: Hans Richter was a German born artist. His broad and influential position in the art world saw him connected with many movements including the Blue Rider, Cubism, De Stijl, Expressionism, Constructivism, Surrealism and most notably Dada. Richter was a painter, graphic designer and filmmaker. The pieces included in his early works on film mixes both painting and cinematography ideas placing them side by side. The organised movement of his works where space, surface and line are rhythmically arranged make use of pure visual perception. His more illustrative works see many surrealist symbols and the use of the everyday inanimate object. Familiar symbols such as eyeballs, beards, clocks and trains are used. The use of nonsense and repetition combined with film processing techniques such as multiple exposure and layering of negative and positive footage are composed to create a sense of movement and rhythm. These short exciting experimental films certainly attest to Richter’s pivotal role in the development of early twentieth century avant-garde.

results.title: Hans Heysen recollections
results.creator_credit: Eugene Schlusser, Reg McLean and Lion's Den Productions
results.brief_description: A comprehensive and personal documentary about the life of one the most renowned painters of the Australian landscape, Hans Heysen. The program centers around interviews with his surviving children, including the Archibald Prize winning artist Nora Heysen, and focuses on the regions around Hahndorf, South Australia, and the Flinders Ranges where his painting was most prolific. It provides a reflective portrayal of his artistry, his concern for the Australian environment, his wide network of supporters and friends, and his influence on others intertwined with a sensitive study of his personal history.

results.title: Hans Christian Andersen. Vol. 3
results.brief_description: These adaptations of some of Hans Christian Andersen’s stories have been produced as a teaching aid for Australian schools. The presentation has been designed to enhance children’s listening and concentration skills and to inspire their imaginations. Each story is beautifully illustrated with full colour drawings. Narrator Grant Denyer’s lively storytelling comes from his experience in education and television, giving the stories a crisp easy listening feel. Volume three contains “Little tiny Thumbelina”, “The brave tin soldier”, “The money box” and “A brief history of Hans Christian Andersen”.

results.title: Hans Christian Andersen
results.creator_credit: Charles Vidor, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Productions
results.brief_description: The incredibly multi-talented Danny Kaye stars as Hans Christian Andersen, a young cobbler with a special gift for storytelling. We first see Hans in his home town of Odense, Denmark, entertaining the village children with his fascinating tales - much to the displeasure of the schoolmaster. Hans takes off for Copenhagen where he falls hopelessly in love with a ballerina, only to discover she is already married. However, this unrequited love inspires a spectacular 17 minute ballet, “The Little Mermaid”, that is one of the highlights of the film. Finally Hans returns home to the acclaim of his fellow townsfolk. Nominated for six Academy Awards, it is a visual and musical delight with an imaginative score. You will be enchanted by this entertaining and much-loved family film that has delighted both young and old for over forty years.

results.title: Hannibal : the terror of Rome
results.creator_credit: Heiner Stadler, Fernsehproduktions GmbH and Caligard Film
results.brief_description: This film delves into the multi-faceted and mysterious figure of Hannibal, who time after time escaped from the Roman military machine and was therefore idealised and demonized by his enemies like no other man. Aerial photography, computer animation, interviews with military experts and historians, and an expedition using elephants reveal how Hannibal was able to overcome Rome’s natural defensive barrier - the snowy, ice-covered Alps.
